sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a circular loop
message_1: A circular loop of radius 0.1m carries a current of 4A. Calculate the magnetic field at a distance of 0.05m from the center of the loop.
message_2:
To calculate the magnetic field at a distance of 0.05m from the center of the loop, we can use the formula for the magnetic field due to a circular loop:

B = (μ₀ * I * R²) / (2 * (R² + x²)^(3/2))

where:
B is the magnetic field
μ₀ is the permeability of free space (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A)
I is the current (4 A)
R is the radius of the loop (0.1 m)
x is the distance from the center of the loop (0.05 m)

Plugging in the values, we get:

B = (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A * 4 A * (0.1 m)²) / (2 * ((0.1 m)² + (0.05 m)²)^(3/2))

B = (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A * 4 A * 0.01 m²) / (2 * (0.01 m² + 0.0025 m²)^(3/2))

B = (16π × 10^(-7) Tm²) / (2 * (0.0125 m²)^(3/2))

B = (16π × 10^(-7) Tm²) / (2 * 0.02795084971 m³)

B ≈ 3.59 × 10^(-5) T

So, the magnetic field at a distance of 0.05m from the center of the loop is approximately 3.59 × 10^(-5) Tesla.
